unnormalised: The season of report cards and admissions is upon us! It's that time of year when everyone's buzzing about percentages, cut-offs, and entrance exams. Remember the anxiety of waiting for your Class 10 results? I sure do. My cousin, Priya, was a nervous wreck! She needed 85% to get into her dream college for science. Those marks felt like the be-all and end-all back then.

Remember the anxiety of waiting for your Class ten results? I sure do. My cousin, Priya, was a nervous wreck! She needed eighty five percent to get into her dream college for science. Those marks felt like the be-all and end-all back then.

unnormalised: And then there's the whole JEE/NEET saga. The pressure on students to score in the top 1% is immense. My neighbor's son, Rohan, prepped for 2 years straight, going to coaching classes every day after school and scoring 98.7 percentile. It felt like half the city celebrated when he got into IIT Delhi. Talk about high stakes!

unnormalised: But let's be real, is a number really everything? I remember my friend, Aisha, who got only 60% in her boards. Everyone thought she wouldn't go far. But guess what? She's now a successful entrepreneur, running her own online business. Proves that marks aren’t the only indicator of success.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole grading system. CBSE’s system is quite different from ICSE’s. 90% in CBSE might be equivalent to 95% in ICSE, or vice versa. And then there are state boards, each with its own quirks. Navigating all these systems can be quite a headache for students and parents alike.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the competition for seats. The cutoffs for popular courses at Delhi University often go above 99%. Imagine needing almost a perfect score just to get a chance! This intense competition can take a toll on the mental health of students, pushing them to their limits.

unnormalised: My uncle always says, "Marks are important, beta, but they don't define you." And I think he's right. Skill development, creativity, and a passion for learning are just as crucial. Focus on what you enjoy, work hard, and don't let a number dictate your future.

unnormalised: So, to all the students out there awaiting results, remember to breathe. Whether you scored 99% or 60%, there's a path for you. Explore your options, stay positive, and keep learning. And to the parents, support your children and remind them that their worth isn't tied to a mark sheet. All the best!
